details.title: On Start-Up Demonstration Tests Under Exchangeability
details.standardTitle: On Start-Up Demonstration Tests Under Exchangeability

p: Serkan Eryılmaz received a Ph.D. in 2002 in Statistics from Ankara University, Turkey. He is currently an Associate Professor in the Department of Mathematics, Izmir University of Economics, Turkey. His research interests include applied probability, and statistical distribution theory.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Math., Izmir Univ. of Econ., Izmir
authors.name: Serkan Eryilmaz

p: Subhabrata Chakraborti is a Professor of statistics in the department of Information Systems, Statistics, and Management Science at the University of Alabama, USA. His research interests include applications of robust as well as nonparametric statistical methodology, particularly in statistical process control.

details.abstract: Consecutive successes total failures (CSTF) is a well known start-up demonstration test procedure in which a unit under test is accepted when successive start-up attempts produce a specified number of consecutive successes before a specified number of failures; otherwise the unit is rejected, and in both cases testing (the experiment) is terminated. The CSTF procedure is studied here assuming that the probability of a successful start-up is a random variable. Under this assumption, the outcomes of the attempted start-ups are dependent random variables following an exchangeable model. The unconditional, and the conditional probability distributions of the waiting time (length of the test) are derived and studied in this situation. The first two moments of unconditional waiting time distribution are calculated. Numerical and graphical illustrations are provided, and comparisons are made with the corresponding results for the i.i.d. model.

context.text: This is not very practical, so a modified procedure was proposed by Balakrishnan & Chan [2].
Balakrishnan & Chan [2] studied statistical characteristics of the CSTF start-up demonstration test assuming that the individual start-ups are \$s\$-independent.
Then the probability of accepting the unit, and the expected length of the test for \$s\$-independent start-ups are given respectively, by (see, Balakrishnan & Chan [2], and Smith & Griffith [12]) .
Martin [9], and Smith & Griffith [12] extended the results of Balakrishnan & Chan [2] to the case where the individual start-ups follow a first order Markov dependent structure.
